additions.definition: The four rules that focus safety services for collective funding: (1) Risk Pooling - sizing for worst days not average, (2) Time Pressure - emergencies are bad for shopping, (3) Impartiality - 'we will come, whoever you are', (4) Standardization - drilled competence that works in the dark
components: Risk Pooling: 'We build a shared system sized for the worst days, not the average ones'
Time Pressure: 'When your kid isn't breathing, you're not in a negotiation mood'
Impartiality: 'If you are in danger, we will come - whoever you are'
Standardization: 'You want the same CPR in every living room'
additions.purpose: Explains WHEN shared needs should be socialized - not ideology, but practical necessity

additions.definition: Satirical thought experiment: 'It's like Uber, but for house fires. Tap a button, and competing fire crews bid on your emergency.' Demonstrates why market logic fails for emergency services.
additions.builds_on: Common startup pitch format applied to obviously wrong domain
additions.purpose: Makes visceral the absurdity of marketizing emergency response
additions.key_quote: Emergencies are a bad time for shopping
additions.first_mention: Chapter 4, 'Why Safety Wants to Be Socialized' section

additions.definition: The messy, non-ideological path from private/volunteer systems to professional public safety: rival fire companies brawling while buildings burned, night watchmen for hire, citizen militias giving way to standing armies
additions.purpose: Shows we backed into public safety because 'the old ways kept burning down', not through philosophical design
key_examples: 18th-19th century: Private fire companies racing each other, fighting over who gets to save the building
Early policing: Night watchmen, private muscle, sheriffs and posses
Military: From citizen-soldiers to standing armies as industrial warfare made militias unrealistic
additions.pattern: Make safety someone's job (not hobby), fund it collectively (not subscriptions), aim it at everyone (not just the powerful)
additions.first_mention: Chapter 4, 'How We Stumbled Into Professional Safety' section

chapter_themes: The commons of safety as socialism's proper habitat
Four features that make safety naturally collective: risk pooling, time pressure, impartiality, standardization
The uniform and split self - flipping from partial love to impartial justice
Safety shell eating the world - police state and securitization
Paradox of boring safety - working well means barely noticed
Shell and engine - safety consumes, markets produce
Habitats as interdependent layers, not rival religions

extraction_notes.chapter_narrative_role: Chapter 4 provides the deep dive into socialism's proper habitat: collectively funded safety services. Opens with visceral fire scene, explains why safety wants to be socialized (four features), explores the split self of uniformed workers, warns about safety eating everything (police state), and closes by asking who pays for it all - setting up Chapter 5's market discussion.
